State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan Shanxi 030024 China 1 Represents co-first authors and contributed equally to this work. Achieving an optimal acid-base synergy and uniform dispersion of active sites on catalyst surface is essential for high catalytic performance in the side chain alkylation of toluene with methanol (SATM). Herein, we report that ammonium (NH₃) treatment of Cu-modified NaX zeolite catalysts effectively modulates acid-base properties and enhances the dispersion of Cu active sites across the catalyst surface. A series of Cu-modified catalysts were prepared with and without NH₃ treatment and further modified with NaOH to evaluate their synergistic effects. Comprehensive characterization techniques, including Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), HAADF-STEM and EDS, Pyridine FTIR, Temperature-Programmed Desorption of NH₃ (TPD-NH₃), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS O 1 s), and regression analysis, were used to correlate catalyst structure, and acid-base property and nature of acid sites with catalytic performance. Results reveal that NH₃ incorporation into the Cu-modified NaX framework significantly enhances catalytic efficiency by tuning acid-base properties and promoting a homogeneous distribution of Cu active sites. Notably, the 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst achieved a superior yield of ethylbenzene and styrene production, reaching 84.9 %, compared to 64.3 % for the 3Cu-4Na catalyst under identical conditions. Methanol conversion reached 97.7 %, with the catalyst demonstrating robust stability over 168 h of operation. Additionally, 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst exhibited the highest turnover frequency (TOF) reaching 27.3 h-1, confirming its superior intrinsic activity. This study highlights the critical role of NH₃ in advancing Cu-NaX catalysts for SATM and provides a promising strategy for optimizing catalytic performance through controlled acid-base interactions and active site dispersion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3-assisted Cu Side chain alkylation Uniform dispersion NaX zeolite Acid-base property Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Styrene and ethylbenzene are used primarily as raw materials in various fields such as agriculture, medicine, and polymer [1]. Traditionally, these compounds are produced via the Friedel–Crafts alkylation process, which involves the ethylation of benzene with ethylene. However, this route faces several challenges, including high production costs, complex multi-step processing, substantial energy demands, and rapid catalyst deactivation [2,3]. As an alternative, Sidorenko first introduced SATM in 1967. SATM offers a promising one-step method for producing styrene and ethylbenzene, with advantages such as lower energy requirements, fewer processing facilities, reduced environmental impact, and lower raw material costs [4–6]. Initially, SATM was believed to be purely base-catalyzed [7,8]. Further studies revealed that SATM is an acid-base synergistic catalysis process, and harmony between basicity and acidity is the key requirement of the catalyst required for this reaction [2–4,9]. In this context, acid sites facilitate to adsorb and stabilize toluene, while base sites promote the activation of methyl group on toluene and catalyze methanol dehydrogenation to formaldehyde (HCHO) [10–12]. Thus, developing a catalyst with tailored acid-base properties is crucial for managing each reaction step in SATM. Zeolite X is a strong candidate for this purpose, given its tunable acid-base characteristics and suitable pore structure, making it ideal for facilitating SATM reactions [11–13]. Alkali metal oxides, when incorporated into X zeolites, enhance toluene activation and foster the formation of formaldehyde, the effective alkylating agent produced by methanol dehydrogenation on alkali-modified sites [6,10,14]. For instance, Han et al. discovered that introducing dehydrogenation components such as Na2B4O7 and CuO into X zeolite improved the catalytic activity of SATM [11,15]. Another research found that introducing Cu not only facilitates methanol dehydrogenation to formaldehyde but also modulates the acid-base property of the catalyst, thus suppressing the undesired transfer hydrogenation of styrene to ethylbenzene [16]. Our prior work found that Cu, particularly low valence Cu, enhances methanol conversion and selectivity of side chain alkylation products [17]. Recent research has explored ammonia (NH3) as a reducing agent to assist non-oxidative methanol dehydrogenation in heterogeneous catalysis [18,19]. As NH3 molecules can regulate the density of acid-base sites in supercages of FAU zeolite [20]. To optimize Cu loading on NaX zeolite, we introduced NH3 as a complexing agent to improve Cu distribution within the NaX structure, followed by NaOH treatment using an impregnation method to achieve optimal acid-base properties. Through a suite of characterization techniques, i.e., XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, SEM, FTIR, and linear regression analysis, we observed that NH3-assisted Cu complexation significantly enhances overall selectivity and yield of styrene and ethylbenzene. Moreover, acid-base properties were analyzed by NH3-TPD and XPS O 1 s and further validated through Pyridine FTIR to determine the synergistic effect of base sites (medium and strong base sites) together with weak Lewis acid sites for synthesizing side chain alkylation products. In addition, turnover frequency (TOF) calculations were performed to evaluate the intrinsic catalytic activity, demonstrating the superior performance of NH₃-treated Cu-modified catalysts. These findings could be beneficial to provide insight into an NH3-based NaX zeolite catalyst design for SATM. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods The following reagents, including ammonia solution (NH3), copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH), were obtained from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. Other reagents such as methanol (CH3OH), toluene (C6H5CH3), and anhydrous ethanol (C2H5OH) were purchased from Tianjin Zhiyuan Chemical reagent Co., Ltd. NaX zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3 = 2.4) was purchased from Nankai University. All the above reagents are in pure analytical form. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Cu-modified NaX zeolite catalysts (3Cu-4Na and 3Cu-6Na) were prepared by loading a fixed concentration of 3 wt% Cu(NO3)2 and different concentrations (4 wt% and 6 wt%) of NaOH on NaX zeolite (Si/Al=1.24) at room temperature (25 °C) by impregnation method followed by direct evaporation. Typically, 10 g of NaX zeolite was added into 50 mL of aqueous solution of 3 wt% Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O. After stirring for 4−5 h at 25 °C, solution was kept in the oven for about 17 h at 80 °C without filtration and then calcinated at 500 °C. Then, different concentrations (4 wt% and 6 wt%) of NaOH were loaded on the obtained solid according to the same procedure as loading Cu(NO3)2. After the same drying and calcination treatment, the obtained solid catalysts were denoted as 3Cu-4Na and 3Cu-6Na, respectively. NH3-assisted catalysts (3Cu-4Na-N and 3Cu-6Na-N) were prepared by loading a 4:1 (NH3 solution:Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O) NH3 solution and fixed concentration 3 wt% Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O followed by the loading of NaOH on NaX zeolite (Si/Al=1.24) at room temperature (25 °C) by impregnation method. Typically, 3.2 mL of NH3 solution was added into 50 mL of aqueous solution of 3 wt% Cu(NO3)2 and stirred for 30 min, then 10 g of NaX zeolite was added in NH3-treated Cu solution. The mixture was stirred for 4−5 h at room temperature (25 °C). Then, the drying, calcination, and loading of NaOH steps are the same as described above. The catalysts obtained after these treatments were named 3Cu-4Na-N and 3Cu-6Na-N, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder XRD patterns were obtained using a Rigaku D/max 2500 X-ray diffractometer equipped with Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm, 40 kV, 100 mA). The measurements were carried out at a scanning rate of 10°/min at 2θ range of 5°–80°. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of catalysts were measured on a BELSORP-mini physisorption apparatus (Microtrac BEL, Japan) at 77 K. Before analysis, samples were degassed under vacuum at 573 K for 6 h. The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) method was used to determine the surface area (S BET), and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore volume method was used to examine the total pore volume distribution. The standard Deviation of Fit (DFT) method was employed to calculate the total pore volume and the mesopore size. SEM and EDS mapping were performed using a JESOL JSM-6010PLUS/LV scanning microscope operating at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. The catalysts were mounted on vacuum-coated gold film before taking images. FT-IR spectra were recorded using VERTEX 70 infrared spectrometer (Bruker, USA). The catalyst samples were mixed with 0.1 g of KBr, and after performing a blank scan, the samples were scanned within a range of 400–4000 cm-1 at a resolution of 4 cm-1. Pyridine adsorption FT-IR measurements were performed on the same instrument to determine the nature of acid sites. Powder samples were pretreated at 450 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 50 °C and adsorbing pyridine, samples were evacuated at 50, 150, 250, and 350 °C for 30 min. IR spectra were separately recorded in the range of 1700−1400 cm-1 using coaddition with 32 scans. XPS was conducted using an Escalab 250 (Thermo Fisher VG) spectrometer with monochromatized Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) at 50 W as the X-ray source. During analysis, the base pressure was maintained at 2 × 10−9 Pa, and binding energies were calibrated against the carbonaceous C1s signal at 284.6 eV. Elemental composition analysis was performed using XRF on an Epsilon1 spectrometer. The data was evaluated using a silicon drift detector (SDD5) and silver (Ag) target at 100 µA and 50 kV. The acidic properties of the samples were analyzed using NH3 temperature-programmed desorption of adsorbed on a TP-5080. Approximately 0.1 g of sample was degassed in a helium stream at 450 °C for 1.5 h, then cooling to 50 °C. The samples were exposed to pure NH3 at 50 °C for 30 min, and the residual NH3 was removed by flushing with helium at 50 °C for 30 min. Subsequently, samples were heated at a rate of 10 °C min-1 from 50 °C to 810 °C, and the desorbed NH3 was detected using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.4 Activity measurements The performance of synthesized catalysts for SATM was carried out at 1 atm pressure in a horizontal fixed-bed reactor. Typically, 1.2 g (40−60 mesh) of the catalyst sample was loaded in a fixed bed reactor. The catalyst was purged with N2 at about 450 °C for 2 h before introducing reactants and then cooled to reaction temperature (425 °C). A mixture of toluene and methanol with a 5:1 M ratio was injected over the catalysts at a rate of 0.8 mL·h-1 with a nitrogen gas stream at a flow rate of 3 mL min-1. The reaction products were detected in an online Haixin GC950 gas chromatograph with a capillary column (0.53 mm × 50 µm) connected to a hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID). The calculation of methanol conversion (CMeth ), product selectivity (SX ), and yield (YX ) were calculated using the following formulas: C M e t h = ( 1 − n M e t h o u t l e t n M e t h i n l e t ) × 100 % S X = ( n x n M e t h inlet − n M e t h outlet ) × 100 % Y X = S X × C M e t h The CMeth represent conversion of methanol, while the selectivity and yield of a specific product X are represented as SX and YX , respectively. nMeth outlet and nMeth inlet are the mole numbers of methanol at the inlet and outlet, respectively. nX is the carbon mole number of a specific product. X includes methane (CH4), xylene (XY), formaldehyde (HCHO), ethylbenzene (EB), and styrene (STY). To comprehensively evaluate the intrinsic catalytic activity, turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated using methanol as the basis. The TOF calculation follows a structured approach incorporating the reaction rate of the desired products (styrene and ethylbenzene) per unit mass of catalyst, normalized by the estimated number of active sites. R e a c t i o n r a t e = Moles of desired products formed ( STY + EB ) Mass of catalyst × Time ( h ) T O F = Reaction rate ( mol g − 1 h − 1 ) A c t i v e s i t e d e n s i t y ( mol g − 1 ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural properties The crystalline structure of the modified catalysts is investigated, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). All modified catalysts show obvious characteristic peaks of octahedral zeolite FAU structure [21,22], It is worth noting that compared to NaX, the peak intensities of all modified catalysts decrease to some extent. Most importantly, the peak intensities of 3Cu-4Na-N and 3Cu-6Na-N are lower compared to 3Cu-4Na and 3Cu-6Na, indicating that copper ions create complex with NH3, and the resulting complex goes into pores and channels of the catalysts, thereby making active sites (Cu species) well dispersed and easily available for reaction. N2 adsorption/desorption results are shown in Fig. 1(b−c) and enlisted Table 1 . Fig. 1(b) clearly illustrates that all modified catalysts exhibit reversible type 1 physisorption isotherms, confirming the presence of both mesopores and micropores in the catalysts. The pore size distribution diagram (Fig. 1c) shows that all modified catalysts contain the feature of micropores concentrated on two centers typically ranging between 0.58 nm and 0.67 nm, which could be attributed to the pore diameter of 12-ring cage and 8-ring cage in NaX, respectively. More specifically, 3Cu-4Na-N and 3Cu-6Na catalysts have the micropore center at 0.58 nm, while 3Cu-4Na and 3Cu-6Na-N catalysts contain the micropore center at 0.67 nm. Compared with that of 3Cu-4Na and 3Cu-6Na catalysts, the micropore size of 3Cu-4Na-N and 3Cu-6Na-N catalysts gradually increases and converts to mesopores as shown in Fig. 1(d), indicating that NH3 facilitates the pore widening due to the complexation with Cu. Table 1 displays the textural parameters of different catalysts. The decrease in micropore volume and total pore volume indicates that introducing NH3 might facilitate the formation of larger Cu particles or clusters during the complexation process, facilitating the formation of mesopores, which can possibly improve the molecular diffusion [23] between reactant and intermediates, that might be the reason for enhanced catalytic performance of 3Cu-4Na-N compared to other catalysts. SEM images were employed to visualize the morphology of modified catalysts. The catalysts 3Cu-4Na and 3Cu-6Na depicted in Fig. 2 (a & c) show the octahedral typical morphology of the NaX zeolite with a smooth appearance. In contrast, 3Cu-4Na-N and 3Cu-6Na-N catalysts in Fig. 2(b & d) appeared as agglomerates, or they possess a rough texture, which can be attributed to a partial collapse of the zeolite framework and are helpful to form additional mesopores. Additionally, 3Cu-4Na-N has shown a well-preserved crystal structure consistent with XRD results. Simultaneously, the elemental distribution on 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst surface was characterized by HAADF-STEM and EDS images, as shown in Fig 2(e). It can be seen that Na, Cu, N, Al, and Si are evenly distributed on the catalyst surface, which accounts for the promising performance of the 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst. FTIR was employed to analyze functional groups present in different catalysts (Fig. 3 ). Results indicated that the absorption bands of all catalysts are the same, suggesting that the addition of NH3 does not completely destroy the faujasite structure of the catalyst. The absorption band at 3468 cm-1 corresponds to the stretching vibration of O−H [24], and the absorption band at 1637 cm-1 refers to the bending vibration of physically adsorbed water [25]. The strongest band near 978 cm-1 is attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the tetrahedron in the NaX structure [26]. Moreover, band intensity at this position initially increases and decreases gradually, suggesting that the Si−O−Al−O structure remains in 3Cu-4Na and 3Cu-6Na catalysts. The absorption peaks at 758 cm-1 and 668 cm-1 appeared due to symmetric stretching vibration of the tetrahedron in the X zeolite framework. The bands at 559 cm-1 and 452 cm-1 are attributed to the vibration of Al−O−Si [27] and the bending vibration of Si−O−Si [28] in the molecular sieve, respectively. Notably, compared with NaX, all Cu-modified catalysts have shown an absorption band at 1383 cm-1, which is ascribed to the symmetric stretching vibration of nitrate ions (NO3 -) [29]. Interestingly, the absorption bands of 3Cu-4Na-N and 3Cu-6Na-N are sharper, and relative intensity increased compared with 3Cu-4Na and 3Cu-6Na, indicating that NH3 helps Cu to penetrate NaX zeolite framework, which accounts for enhanced catalytic performance of these catalysts. XPS characterization was performed to determine the states of Na and O elements on the surface of modified catalysts (Fig. 4 ). Fig. 4(a) shows that XPS peaks of Na 1 s shift towards a low binding energy direction from 1072.08 eV of parent NaX zeolite to 1071.78 eV of 3Cu-6Na and 3Cu-4Na-N catalysts, indicating that with loading certain amount of NaOH, the electronegativity of Na element on the catalyst surface increases. XPS peaks of O 1 s in Fig. 4(b) also show the same trend of shifting towards low binding energy, with 3Cu-4Na-N showing the least binding energy of 531.22 eV, indicating that electron density of the O element on the surface of 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst surface increases, which enhances the basicity of catalyst and accounts for the enhanced catalytic performance. Cu is widely known for its dehydrogenation effect, which facilitates the C−H bond activation in methyl group of toluene and methanol [17]. XPS peaks of Cu 2p3/2 for modified catalysts are shown in Fig. 4(c). The Cu 2p3/2 spectra are deconvoluted into two distinct peaks corresponding to Cu2+ ions at around 934.6 eV and a low valenced Cuδ+ species (where 0 ≤ δ < 1) at around 932.5 eV [30–32], respectively. Results reveal that the proportion of low-valence Cuδ+ species is dominant in all catalysts, and the highest proportion of low-valence Cuδ+ species reaches up to 76.8 % in 3Cu-4Na catalysts, as shown in Table S1 and Fig 4(c). Table S2 shows a perfect linear correlation between Cuδ+ percentage and selectivity as well as yield of ethylbenzene, indicating that low-valenced Cuδ+ induced the production of ethylbenzene due to its excellent dehydrogenation ability, hence promoting the SATM. 3.2 Acid-base distribution analysis The NH3-TPD results in Fig. 5(a) revealed that all catalysts show a prominent peak within the temperature range of 100 °C to 300 °C, indicating the presence of both weak and medium-strong acid sites. Interestingly, in the NH3-assisted Cu-modified NaX catalysts, NH3 desorption peak area decreases, indicating that intensity and amount of acid sites on the surface of the catalysts decrease. Moreover, NH3 desorption peaks move towards the low-temperature region, and the percentage of weak acid sites increases from 29.6 % of NaX zeolite to 89.2 % of 3Cu-6Na-N. In comparison, the percentage of medium-strong acid sites reduces from 31.1 % of the parent NaX zeolite to 10.7 % of 3Cu-6Na-N, as shown in Table 2 . This increase in the proportion of weak acid sites is beneficial for the adsorption and stabilization of toluene. Notably, 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst shows the highest percentage (33.6 %) of medium-strong acid sites, signifying that NH3 complexation with Cu assists in regulating the acidity of the catalyst. Pyridine-adsorbed FTIR spectroscopy was conducted to investigate the nature of acid sites in modified catalysts as shown in Fig. S1. The pyridine-IR spectra shown in Fig. S1 confirmed that the acid sites are exclusively Lewis in nature, which have been demonstrated to be active sites for the adsorption and stabilization of toluene. The bands usually at 1538 cm⁻¹ could be ascribed to pyridine−Brønsted acid sites. While the bands at ∼1440 cm⁻¹ and 1590 cm⁻¹ are attributed to pyridine−Lewis acid sites[33,34]. Fig. S1(a & b) shows that a distinct band at 1440 cm⁻¹ appears in 3Cu-4Na and 3Cu-4Na-N catalysts at elevated temperatures (150, 250, and 350 °C) indicates the presence of thermally stable Lewis acid sites. In contrast, the absence of this band in 3Cu-6Na and 3Cu-6Na-N (Fig. S1 (c & d)) catalysts at higher temperatures (150, 250, and 350 °C) suggests that higher NaOH loading leads to either the weakening or transformation of these Lewis acid sites, potentially due to a stronger basic environment. Moreover, a band observed at around 1486 cm⁻¹ may represent the contribution of both acid sites (Lewis and Brønsted) together [35]. Furthermore, the band at around 1538 cm⁻¹, typically associated with Brønsted acid sites, is very low or nearly absent in our spectra. This observation confirms that all the modified catalysts possess minimal Brønsted acidity, reinforcing that the active acid sites are predominantly Lewis in nature that are critical for the effective adsorption and activation of toluene, which is essential for promoting the desired side chain alkylation reaction. Our previous report described the limitation of using TPD-CO2 for determining the basicity of the modified NaX catalyst [36]. Therefore, O 1 s XPS is used to effectively evaluate the basicity of the catalyst by analyzing the changes in binding energy. The distribution of basic sites in Table 2 and Fig. 5 (b) is deconvoluted to calculate the area proportion of each basic site. It is revealed that in the NH3-assisted Cu-modified NaX catalysts, the proportion of middle base sites on the catalyst gradually decreases from 66.3 % of 3Cu-4Na catalyst to 48.7 % of 3Cu-4Na-N and from 65.8 % of 3Cu-6Na to 43.9 % of 3Cu-6Na-N catalyst. Simultaneously, the proportion of strong base sites increases in NH3-assisted Cu-modified catalysts, as seen in Table 2. A linear regression analysis was used to investigate the underlying principles by examining the relationship between the acid-base properties and catalytic performance of modified catalysts (Table S2). The selectivity of ethylbenzene (SEB) and the yield of ethylbenzene (YEB) have an excellent linear correlation with the ratio of middle base site percentage to weak acid site percentage (MB/WA), both showing a correlation coefficient (R) of 0.86, indicating that the combination of middle base and weak acid sites play an important role in ethylbenzene synthesis. Notably, the total yield of ethylbenzene and styrene (YEB+STY) has a perfect relationship with the percentage of middle and strong base sites and percentage of weak acid [(MB+SB) × WA], with a correlation coefficient (R) of 0.82. This can be ascribed to the combined contribution of middle and strong base sites along with weak acid sites [36]. These findings suggest that the synergistic effect of middle and strong base sites with weak acid sites promotes the formation of side chain alkylation products (ethylbenzene and styrene). 3.3 Catalytic reactions 3.3.1 Comparison of catalyst performance The catalytic testing for SATM was done for modified catalysts, and the performance of each catalyst is shown in Fig. 6 and enlisted in Table 3 . Firstly, NaX zeolite has shown a relatively low catalytic performance without any modification. The performance improved significantly when NaX was modified with Cu and impregnated with NaOH. Notably, 3Cu-6Na exhibits the higher total selectivity and yield of side chain alkylation products at 83.8 % and 78.6 %, respectively, with a methanol conversion reaching 94.6 %. Moreover, the styrene selectivity increased from 2.9 % of 3Cu-4Na to 31.3 % of 3Cu-6Na catalyst. It signifies that Cu plays a significant role in activating the C-H bond and forming side chain alkylation products. Meanwhile, NH3-assisted Cu-modified NaX catalysts, especially 3Cu-4Na-N, have shown the highest side chain alkylation products than 3Cu-4Na, indicating that introducing NH3 is responsible for superior catalytic performance. Typically, the overall selectivity and yield of ethylbenzene and styrene for 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst are 86.8 % and 84.9 %, respectively. In contrast, the total selectivity and yield of ethylbenzene and styrene of 3Cu-4Na are only 67.8 % and 64.3 %, respectively, under the same reaction conditions. Moreover, the methanol conversion improves from 94.6 % of 3Cu-4Na to 97.7 % of 3Cu-4Na-N (Table 3). This indicates that introducing NH3 into a Cu-modified NaX catalyst enhances the methanol conversion in SATM. Similarly, the methanol conversion and selectivity and yield of ethylbenzene enhanced in 3Cu-6Na-N compared to 3Cu-6Na, however, the styrene selectivity reduced significantly. The enhanced catalytic performance of 3Cu-4Na-N might be due to the addition of NH3 with the dehydrogenation component (Cu) and regulating the alkalinity by loading an appropriate amount (4 wt%) of NaOH that promotes the methanol dehydrogenation to formaldehyde and activates toluene methyl groups. Moreover, NH3 creates a complex with Cu to make it better loaded onto the catalyst, thereby improving the catalytic performance. To further evaluate the intrinsic catalytic activity of modified catalysts, the turnover frequency (TOF) was determined by normalizing the rate of product formation (styrene and ethylbenzene) per gram of catalyst to the estimated number of active sites. As seen in Table S3, the TOF of 3Cu-4Na-N (27.3 h⁻¹) is significantly higher than that of 3Cu-4Na (20 h⁻¹), indicating that NH₃ treatment effectively enhances catalytic site accessibility and reaction kinetics. A similar trend was observed for 3Cu-6Na-N (20 h⁻¹) and 3Cu-6Na (24.3 h⁻¹), where the NH₃-modified catalyst exhibits slightly reduced TOF, which may be due to structural changes in active site distribution affecting catalytic efficiency. These results indicate that the superior catalytic performance of NH₃-assisted Cu-modified NaX catalysts results from enhanced methanol conversion and improved active site utilization, as reflected by their higher TOF values. The TOF values further confirm the selectivity trends, where 3Cu-4Na-N shows the highest TOF, associated with its optimal balance of Lewis acid sites and basicity. The high intrinsic activity of the 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst suggests that NH₃ treatment facilitates Cu dispersion and fine-tunes acid-base properties, ultimately leading to methanol dehydrogenation and enhanced C–H bond activation. These findings further confirm the potential role of NH₃ in improving catalytic activity in SATM. 3.3.2 Catalytic stability The catalytic stability of the modified catalysts was examined for SATM (Fig. 7 ). All modified catalysts showed very stable catalytic performance without obvious deactivation during the evaluation period (144–170 h). It is noteworthy that, despite the observed decrease in BET surface area and micropore volume after continued reaction, these changes possibly reflect a partial collapse of NaX structure that may expose previously inaccessible active sites, leading to the formation of new mesopores, thereby enhancing the diffusion of reactants and intermediates. This might be the reason that the selectivity of ethylbenzene, total yield of ethylbenzene and styrene, and the methanol conversion of all modified catalysts remain stable when the reaction proceeds. Simultaneously, XPS O 1 s analysis revealed a shift towards lower binding energy, which indicates that increased electron density on surface oxygen species and enhanced basicity are essential for methanol dehydrogenation. Moreover, an optimal MB/WA ratio (0.68–0.86) suggests that the critical acid-base balance is preserved, leading to the high yields of ethylbenzene and styrene over extended reaction times. Particularly, 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst exhibits a high total yield of ethylbenzene and styrene, with an average of 80.89 % throughout the reaction. The average methanol conversion of 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst is about 97.79 % in 168 h (Figs. 6& 7). Some characterizations such as XRD, BET, TPD-NH3, and XPS O 1 s for 3Cu-6Na and 3Cu-4Na-N after the reaction were performed to determine the difference between the two catalysts and the reason for their good stability. Fig. 8 (a) shows XRD patterns of 3Cu-6Na and 3Cu-4Na-N catalysts before and after reaction. The chemical composition of 3Cu-6Na and 3Cu-4Na-N after the reaction appears to be the same as before reaction. However, peak intensity becomes weaker after reaction, indicating the partial damage of NaX framework, which could potentially assist in exposing more active sites, thereby promoting the reaction. The N2 adsorption-desorption results further confirm the structural damage of NaX because the specific surface area of 3Cu-6Na and 3Cu-4Na-N catalysts decreased by 84.5 % and 53.7 %, respectively, after the reaction (Table 4 and Fig. 8(b−d)). Despite the decrease in the surface area, both catalysts still show stable catalytic performance. To determine the actual influencing factor, the acid-base properties of 3Cu-6Na and 3Cu-4Na-N catalysts were examined using TPD-NH3 and XPS O 1 s before and after reaction (Fig. 9 and Table 5 ). Interestingly, the proportion of weak acid sites significantly increased by 10.6 % in 3Cu-6Na and 31.2 % in 3Cu-4Na-N, respectively, after the reaction. Simultaneously, middle base sites decreased by 1.1 % and increased by 22.4 % in 3Cu-6Na and 3Cu-4Na-N after the reaction. These results reveal that the enhanced total yield of ethylbenzene and styrene, along with the excellent stability of the 3Cu-6Na and 3Cu-4Na-N catalysts, can be attributed to the synergistic interaction between the middle base and weak acid sites (MB/WA) in these catalysts as discussed in our previous work[17,37]. The yield of ethylbenzene and styrene will be stable when ratio MB/WA falls within the range of 0.68 to 0.86 (Table 5). The shifts observed in the XPS O 1 s spectra and changes in the NH₃-TPD profiles post-reaction further support the ability of the catalyst to maintain an effective distribution of active sites. These modifications indicate an increase in catalyst basicity and a favorable alteration in acid-base site ratios, which are crucial for the long-term stability and performance of the catalyst. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism The proposed reaction mechanism for the SATM over modified NaX catalysts is illustrated in Fig. 10 . Initially, methanol is adsorbed on the catalyst surface and undergoes dehydrogenation at the Cu sites to form methoxy species (CH₃O*) and hydrogen (H₂). At the same time, toluene is activated on the base sites of the catalyst, particularly the middle base sites, while weak acid sites, mainly Lewis's acid sites as confirmed by pyridine FTIR, stabilize the activated toluene. A simultaneous generation of sufficient middle base sites and abundant weak acid sites on the catalyst allows to convert methoxy species into reactive intermediates (e.g., CH₃⁺ or CH₂OH⁺), which then couple with the activated toluene to produce styrene and ethylbenzene (RT1). When NH₃ is introduced prior to Cu incorporation, the resulting NH₃-assisted Cu-modified catalysts display enhanced Cu dispersion and a fine-tuned acid–base profile, further promoting methanol dehydrogenation and toluene activation, as evidenced by higher turnover frequency (TOF) values (RT2). In contrast, an excessive acidic environment favors aromatic alkylation, leading to the formation of xylene byproducts. Thus, the overall catalytic performance and stability of our NH₃-assisted Cu-modified NaX catalysts are attributed to the optimized balance between weak acid sites and middle base sites, which maximizes active site utilization and suppresses undesired side reactions. 4 Conclusion In summary, the introduction of NH₃ as a complexing agent in Cu-modified NaX zeolite catalysts, followed by NaOH treatment, effectively optimizes acid-base properties, resulting in superior catalytic performance and stability for SATM. The optimized 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst demonstrated a high total yield of ethylbenzene and styrene (84.9 %) and a substantial methanol conversion rate of 97.7 %, maintaining stability over 168 h. Characterization analyses (XRD, SEM, TPD-NH₃, XPS O 1 s and Pyridine FTIR) combined with linear regression reveal that NH₃ facilitates the penetration and dispersion of Cu within NaX zeolite, promoting pore widening and a uniform distribution of active sites that enhance both catalytic performance and long life. Pyridine FTIR confirmed that the acid sites are predominantly Lewis in nature, that is critical for effective toluene adsorption and activation. Moreover, TOF calculations demonstrate the intrinsic catalytic efficiency of the optimized catalyst, highlighting the effective utilization of active sites. This study offers a promising approach for advancing SATM catalyst design, underscoring the importance of acid-base synergy and active site dispersion. coredata.dc:description: Achieving an optimal acid-base synergy and uniform dispersion of active sites on catalyst surface is essential for high catalytic performance in the side chain alkylation of toluene with methanol (SATM). Herein, we report that ammonium (NH₃) treatment of Cu-modified NaX zeolite catalysts effectively modulates acid-base properties and enhances the dispersion of Cu active sites across the catalyst surface. A series of Cu-modified catalysts were prepared with and without NH₃ treatment and further modified with NaOH to evaluate their synergistic effects. Comprehensive characterization techniques, including Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), HAADF-STEM and EDS, Pyridine FTIR, Temperature-Programmed Desorption of NH₃ (TPD-NH₃), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS O 1 s), and regression analysis, were used to correlate catalyst structure, and acid-base property and nature of acid sites with catalytic performance. Results reveal that NH₃ incorporation into the Cu-modified NaX framework significantly enhances catalytic efficiency by tuning acid-base properties and promoting a homogeneous distribution of Cu active sites. Notably, the 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst achieved a superior yield of ethylbenzene and styrene production, reaching 84.9 %, compared to 64.3 % for the 3Cu-4Na catalyst under identical conditions. Methanol conversion reached 97.7 %, with the catalyst demonstrating robust stability over 168 h of operation. Additionally, 3Cu-4Na-N catalyst exhibited the highest turnover frequency (TOF) reaching 27.3 h-1, confirming its superior intrinsic activity. This study highlights the critical role of NH₃ in advancing Cu-NaX catalysts for SATM and provides a promising strategy for optimizing catalytic performance through controlled acid-base interactions and active site dispersion.
